title: What is Soroban? A Mom's Honest Review After 6 Months
description: Soroban is the Japanese abacus that helps kids develop lightning-fast mental math. Here's my real experience after 6 months - what worked, what didn't, and whether it's worth it for American families.
imageAlt: Child learning mental math with Soroban abacus

content.intro: The first time I heard 'Soroban,' I thought it was a sushi roll. Seriously. Then I saw a video of a 7-year-old mentally calculating five 3-digit numbers in seconds – no calculator, no paper, just closing her eyes and giving the answer. Correct. I couldn't believe it. Meanwhile, my 8-year-old still counts on his fingers for 47 + 38.

sections.text: That video sent me down a rabbit hole. After 6 months of my son learning Soroban, I want to share what I've learned – not as an expert, but as a mom who tried it and saw real results.
If you're wondering what Soroban is and whether it's right for your kid, this is everything I wish I'd known before we started.
What is Soroban? The Simple Explanation

Soroban is the Japanese abacus – a traditional calculating tool that originated from the Chinese abacus (Suanpan) but was refined by the Japanese for faster calculations. It has columns of beads: 1 bead on top (worth 5) and 4 beads on the bottom (each worth 1).

Sounds complicated? I thought so too at first. But the principle is actually simple: instead of counting 1, 2, 3... kids learn to 'see' numbers by the position of beads. It's like reading a clock – you glance at it and instantly know the time without counting each minute marker.
Why Does Soroban Help with Mental Math?

This is the mind-blowing part. After enough practice, kids don't need the physical abacus anymore. They visualize it in their head and 'move' imaginary beads. This is called 'Anzan' – mental calculation using visualization.

The right brain (which processes images) gets activated instead of just the left brain (logic). Result: kids process numbers faster, remember longer, and don't make the mistakes that come from counting one by one.

I explained it to my son this way: 'You know how you can recognize Mom's face instantly without checking each feature? Your brain remembers the whole picture. Soroban works the same way – you'll recognize numbers as pictures.'
Why Are Japanese Kids So Fast at Mental Math?

I used to wonder: how are those kids in YouTube videos so incredibly fast? Turns out, in Japan, Soroban is taught from elementary school – sometimes even kindergarten. It's not treated as an extra subject, but as 'exercise for the brain.' Even in the digital age, Japanese parents have their kids learn Soroban because they believe it trains the brain, not just calculation skills.

Research shows that Soroban-trained children have better focus, longer retention, and faster information processing. Not just in math – in other subjects too. Sounds like marketing hype, but I've seen it in my own kid. After 6 months, his focus has noticeably improved, not just during math.
Our 6-Month Soroban Journey

I won't sugarcoat it – I was totally lost at first. I knew nothing about Soroban, so how could I teach my kid? Soroban centers near us were expensive, far away, and had schedules that didn't work with my job.
Months 1-2: Getting Familiar with the Abacus

I bought a Soroban (about $15) and downloaded the Sorokid app to learn the basics. The first two months were just learning to move beads, recognizing numbers 1-9, then two-digit numbers. Slow, but I didn't rush it.
Some days he got bored and didn't want to practice. I didn't force it. I let him play games on the app, earn stars and badges. He liked the rewards, so gradually he came back to learning.
Months 3-4: Starting Addition and Subtraction

He learned simple addition and subtraction on the abacus. 3 + 5, 7 - 2... problems he already knew, but now solving by moving beads. I noticed he was actually slower than his regular method and wondered: 'Are we going backwards?'
But I'd read somewhere: 'The early stage will be slower because they're building a new foundation. Be patient.' So I stuck with it.
Months 5-6: Starting to See Results

This is when I started saying 'wow.' He didn't need to look at the abacus anymore. He'd close his eyes, his fingers moving in the air (imagining the abacus), then give the answer. 34 + 27 = 61. Correct. 56 - 18 = 38. Correct.
Not 100% accurate every time, but his accuracy rate was way higher than before. And more importantly: he was calculating much faster than before.
One day he came home bragging: 'Mom, the teacher asked a problem today and I got the answer fastest in the whole class!' I don't know if that's true, but seeing him confident made my day.
Is Soroban Right for American Kids?
This was my big question. Soroban is Japanese – would it work for American kids with different learning styles? After 6 months, my answer is: YES, but with some considerations.
What Works Well

items: **American education emphasizes understanding over memorization** – Soroban helps shift from rote memory to visual understanding, which aligns well with Common Core goals
**Standardized tests require speed** – Soroban gives kids an advantage in timed tests where mental math matters
**Kids love games** – Modern Soroban apps use gamification, which American kids respond to really well

sections.text: Things to Keep in Mind

items: **Early stages might conflict with school methods** – Need to explain to kids that this is 'another tool,' not a replacement for what they learn in school
**Requires 3-6 months of patience** – You won't see results in 1-2 weeks; many parents give up too early
**Consistency beats intensity** – 10-15 minutes daily is better than 1 hour on weekends

sections.text: Does Soroban Have Any Downsides?
I want to be honest and share the challenges too, not just the success story.
1. It Takes Time to See Results

This isn't a 'learn for a week, become a genius' method. On average, it takes 3-6 months before kids start doing mental math with visualization. If you need quick results (like for an upcoming test), Soroban might not be the best choice.
2. Initial Confusion is Normal

Kids are used to calculating one way at school, now learning a new way – they might get mixed up. I had to explain clearly: 'This is just another tool, like how you can walk to school or ride your bike – both get you there.'
3. Parental Involvement Matters
Even with an app, kids still need parents nearby to encourage them and explain when they're stuck. If you're too busy and expect the app to do everything, results won't be as good as you'd hope.
I used to think I could just buy the app and be done. Wrong. The weeks I sat with my son for 15 minutes, he improved noticeably. The weeks I was too busy and left him alone, he barely progressed.
What's the Best Age to Start Soroban?
Based on my experience and research:

items: **Ages 4-5:** Can start getting familiar with the abacus, counting beads, no actual math needed yet
**Ages 6-7 (1st-2nd grade):** Ideal age to start formal Soroban learning
**Ages 8-10 (3rd-5th grade):** Still very effective, might progress faster since they already have number sense
**Over 10:** Can still learn but harder to reach advanced levels compared to starting younger

sections.text: My son started at 8 (3rd grade) – not super early, but still showed clear improvement. Starting right matters more than starting early.
How Can Kids Learn Soroban? Options Available
Here are the ways to learn Soroban – pick what works for your family.
1. Soroban Centers/Classes

Direct instruction from teachers, learning environment, peers to practice with. Downsides: expensive (often $100-200/month), requires driving kids there, fixed schedules. Good if you have the time and budget.
2. Online Courses
Video lessons kids can watch anytime. More affordable than classes, flexible timing. Downside: one-way learning, kids can't ask questions in real-time. Good for self-motivated kids.
3. Learning Apps (What We Chose)

Apps like Sorokid turn Soroban into a game. Kids learn through play, earn rewards, track progress. Most affordable option (some have free versions). Downside: need parental support alongside. Good for busy parents who can spare 15 minutes daily.

We chose the app route because I'm a working mom who can't drive my kid to classes. 15 minutes before bedtime worked for us. Some days more, some days less – but consistency mattered more than duration.
The Bottom Line: Should Your Kid Learn Soroban?
After 6 months, here's my honest take:

items: **If your kid struggles with mental math** – Soroban offers a completely different approach that might click where traditional methods haven't
**If you can commit to 3-6 months** – The method needs time; don't expect overnight miracles
**If you can spend 15 minutes daily with your kid** – Parental involvement significantly boosts results
**If your kid enjoys games and rewards** – Modern Soroban apps make learning fun

sections.text: Soroban isn't magic. It's a tool – and like any tool, it works best when used correctly and consistently. For our family, it was worth it. My son is more confident with numbers, faster at calculations, and actually enjoys his daily 'Soroban time.'

Your family might be different. But if you're curious and willing to give it a real try, I'd say go for it. The worst that happens? Your kid learns a new way of looking at numbers. The best? They develop a mental math superpower.

faq.question: What age is best to start learning Soroban?
faq.answer: The ideal age is 6-7 years old (1st-2nd grade), but kids can start as early as 4-5 for basic familiarity or as late as 10 and still see benefits. Starting right matters more than starting early.

faq.question: How long until my child can do mental math with Soroban?
faq.answer: Typically 3-6 months of consistent practice (10-15 minutes daily) before children start visualizing the abacus and calculating mentally. Results vary based on age and practice consistency.

faq.question: Do I need to know Soroban to help my child learn?
faq.answer: No! Modern apps like Sorokid guide both parent and child step by step. You'll learn alongside your child. Many parents find they pick up the basics quickly by watching their kids practice.

faq.question: Will Soroban conflict with what my child learns at school?
faq.answer: Not if introduced correctly. Frame it as 'another tool' rather than a replacement. Kids can use whatever method works best for each situation – school methods for showing work, Soroban for speed.

faq.question: Is Soroban better than Kumon or other math programs?
faq.answer: They're different approaches. Kumon focuses on repetition and worksheets. Soroban focuses on visualization and mental math. Some families use both. Soroban tends to be more engaging for kids who enjoy visual and hands-on learning.
